tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over the counter to take care of this athletes foot.

We are assuming a mild case of athletes foot.

Athletes foot is a fungi infection. It is actually ringworm of the foot.

To take care of this, you will need an antifungal cream, ointment or powder.

One thing to keep in mind while using OTC medications to treat athletes foot is that you have to continue treatment for no less than one extra week after the rash disappears from the skin surface. 

This will make sure it is treated and prevent it from coming back. 

There are different types of creams, gels or powders for athletes foot over-the-counter in the foot care section.

Which should you choose?    

Let's answer a few questions and come to a reasonable decision on what will work best for you.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: Affected area is sore and inflammed.
Area is on the bottom or side of the foot
Affected area is wet or moist (sweaty feet)
I have difficulty keeping the area dry.
Area is swollen, warm to touch.
I see red streaks in affected area.
There is some kind of pus or drainage in the affected area.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.
mode.2: Something to prevent?
mode.3:
Seek Urgent Care Clinic
You will have to see a doctor on this one.
mode.4: Selection require an antifungal cream like terbinafine.
mode.5: Selection require an antifungal cream like clotrimazole.
mode.6: Selection require an anti inflammatory cream such as hydrocortisone 1%.
mode.7: Selection require using an antifungal foot powder or powder spray.
mode.8: Selection require using an astringent like aluminum acetate
mode.9: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing terbinafine or clotrimazole
mode.10: Symptoms require antifungal cream with terbinafine and using hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation
mode.11: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing terbinafine and or antifungal foot powder
mode.12: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing terbinafine and a drying agent like aluminum acetate
mode.13: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing clotrimazole and anti-inflammatory cream containing hydrocortisone 1%
mode.14: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing clotrimazole and a foot powder
mode.15: Symptoms require antifungal cream containing clotrimazole and drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.16: Symptoms require an anti-inflammatory cream containing hydrocortisone 1% and an antifungal foot powder
mode.17: Symptoms require an anti-inflammatory cream containing hydrocortisone 1% and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.18: Symptoms require an antifungal foot powder and drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.19: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole and hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation
mode.20: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole and a foot powder
mode.21: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.22: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a foot powder
mode.23: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.24: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine, foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.25: Symptoms require antifungal cream with clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a foot powder
mode.26: Symptoms require antifungal cream with clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.27: Symptoms require antifungal cream with clotrimazole, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.28: Symptoms require hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.29: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a foot powder
mode.30: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.31: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.32: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.33: Symptoms require antifungal cream with clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.34: Symptoms require an antifungal cream with terbinafine or clotrimazole, hydrocortisone 1% for inflammation, a foot powder and a drying agent with aluminum acetate
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/01/1970

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over the counter to help with plantar fasciitis.

This usually go away on its own, but it often do so in about 6 to 18 months and you obviously want some relief until then.

The earlier it is recognised and treated, the shorter the length of time it will take to handle this.

If what is available over the counter does not provide relief, it is necessary to see a healthcare provider.

Don't delay.

With this in mind, see what is recommended over the counter below.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over the counter to help with arthritis.

Goal of treatment is to reduce pain and further joint damage while improving function.

There are different approaches to arthritis management, we will take a look at over-the-counter remedies available. 

Hope you are under the care of a healthcare professional for this and you are familiar with lifestyle changes, exercise programs and so on.

With this in mind, see what is recommended over-the-counter for arthritis management below:

tabs.header_iregular:
Nail fungus is difficult to treat. Let's take a look.

The objective here is to outline the steps involved in the treatment of nail fungus. You will then have to make a decision on how you want to proceed.

To start with, you will have to see a doctor for the treatment of nail fungus. Preferably a podiatrist.

Don't be fooled by the "before and after" pictures of  toenails and fingernails on the boxes of over-the-counter antifungal liquid advertised for nail fungus. If you read carefully, it would tell you it is not effective on nails. Go figure.

What they are effective for is the surrounding areas and not the nail plate. The reasoning is that some toenail fungi infection do spread to the surrounding skin area and some do come with athlete's foot. If the athlete's foot goes away, then you've gotten your money's worth.

So don't even waste your money on OTC antifungi medications if you think you are looking at a nail fungus.

With this in mind, see what I recommend below.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 10/07/2014
